author: AFP
title: Etats-Unis: les salariés de Boeing votent massivement pour la grève, la direction veut négocier
text:
Envoyer par mail Envoyer Partager sur Facebook Partager Partager sur Twitter Twitter Déjà dans la tourmente après plusieurs accidents, Boeing fait désormais face à sa première grande grève en 16 ans, avec le coup d’envoi vendredi d’un vaste mouvement social qui va bloquer sa production dans son berceau de la côte nord-ouest américaine.
La grève devait démarrer à minuit heure locale (07H00 GMT, selon le syndicat des machinistes IAM-District 751, quelques heures après un vote massif par les salariés de Boeing de la région de Seattle en faveur d’un débrayage.
Selon l’agence Bloomberg, des centaines de travailleurs ont entamé dans la nuit un piquet de grève à l’usine de Renton, proche de Seattle, où est produit le 737 Max, appareil vedette de l’avionneur américain.
Jeudi, les travailleurs ont rejeté la nouvelle convention de travail proposée par l’avionneur à 94,6%, a précisé Jon Holden, président du syndicat des machinistes IAM-District 751.
Ils ont en outre voté à 96% en faveur d’une grève dès l’expiration jeudi à minuit de la convention actuelle, vieille de 16 ans. Les deux tiers des votes étaient nécessaires pour lancer un arrêt de travail.
Le syndicat, qui représente environ 33.000 travailleurs dans la région Nord-Ouest Pacifique, avait initialement soutenu l’accord. M. Holden avait auparavant déclaré ne pas pouvoir « garantir que nous obtiendrons davantage en faisant grève » .
La grève doit entraîner la fermeture de deux grandes usines d’assemblage d’avions dans la région de Puget Sound. Elle va paralyser la production du 737, du 777 et du 767 cargo, dont les livraisons cumulent déjà les retards.
Une situation d’autant plus problématique que l’avionneur encaisse la plus grosse partie du paiement (environ 60%) à la remise des avions.
Boeing toujours prêt à négocier En dépit du vote massif en faveur de la grève, le groupe Boeing a déclaré dans un communiqué être « engagé » dans la négociation.
Jon Holden, président du syndicat IAM-District 751 de Boeing, le 17 juillet 2024 à Seattle (nord-ouest) / Jason Redmond / AFP/Archives
« Nous restons déterminés à rétablir nos relations avec nos employés et le syndicat, et nous sommes prêts à retourner à la table des négociations pour parvenir à un nouvel accord » , a affirmé l’avionneur.
La dernière grève chez l’avionneur américain, en 2008, avait duré 57 jours.
Selon les analystes de TD Cowen, une grève de 50 jours priverait Boeing de 3 à 3,5 milliards de dollars de liquidités et aurait un impact de 5,5 milliards sur le chiffre d’affaires. Dans les échanges électroniques avant l’ouverture de la Bourse de New York vendredi, le titre du constructeur chutait d’ailleurs de près de 4%.
Le vote de jeudi marque un rejet décisif d’un accord qui, selon les travailleurs, était bien moins généreux que ne l’affirmaient les dirigeants de Boeing. Il prévoyait une hausse salariale de 25% sur quatre ans ainsi qu’un engagement d’investissements dans la région, ainsi que la construction du prochain avion - annoncé pour 2035 - dans le berceau historique de l’avionneur, ce qui devait assurer des emplois pour plusieurs décennies.
« Bradés » Boeing espérait que ces concessions suffiraient à esquiver une grève. Sa situation financière est précaire depuis le crash de deux 737 MAX 8 en 2018 et en 2019, ayant coûté la vie à 346 personnes, et une multitude de problèmes de qualité de la production.
Il fait notamment l’objet d’une supervision accrue après la perte d’une porte-bouchon en plein vol début janvier sur un 737 MAX 9 d’Alaska Airlines.
Photo non datée de Kelly Ortberg, patron de Boeing depuis le 8 août 2024 / Handout / BOEING/AFP/Archives
« Ce n’est un secret pour personne: notre activité traverse une période difficile, en partie à cause de nos propres erreurs du passé. (...) Une grève mettrait en péril notre reprise commune » , avait prévenu mercredi soir Kelly Ortberg, qui a succédé le 8 août à Dave Calhoun au poste de directeur général de l’avionneur américain.
Il avait exhorté les employés à ne pas « sacrifier » les progrès futurs en raison de « frustrations liées au passé » .
Mais les mécontents jugent la hausse salariale trop éloignée des demandes du syndicat (+40% initialement) et le volet sur les retraites insatisfaisant.
Une semaine après sa prise de fonction, M. Ortberg s’était engagé à « réinitialiser » la relation avec l’IAM. Mais à la lecture de l’accord, de nombreux syndiqués ont réagi négativement et plaidé pour un arrêt de travail.
« On nous a bradés » , a lancé jeudi à l’AFP Kamie Bryan, employée chez Boeing depuis 18 ans, après avoir voté contre l’accord et pour la grève. « Nous ne devrions pas prendre ces quelques sous qu’ils nous donnent et être reconnaissants » , a-t-elle relevé, insistant sur l’ampleur des « revenus du patron » .
« Ils parlent d’une augmentation de 25%, mais ce n’est pas le cas » , a déclaré Paul Janousek, un électricien d’Everett qui a voté en faveur de la grève après avoir estimé que la présentation de Boeing était « trompeuse » . Selon cet homme de 55 ans, employé chez Boeing depuis 13 ans, son augmentation ne serait en réalité que d’environ 9%, compte tenu de la suppression de la prime annuelle.
Des membres et des soutiens du syndicat international des machinistes et des ouvriers de l'aérospatial (IAM) à Seattle, le 17 juillet 2024 / Jason Redmond / AFP/Archives
Les télévisions ont montré des rassemblements quotidiens d’ouvriers protestant dans les usines contre des mesures salariales qu’ils estiment inadéquates face à l’inflation.
Après des grèves dans les secteurs de l’automobile, du divertissement et d’autres secteurs d’activité, les syndicats engagent ainsi un nouveau bras de fer.
Le règlement de l’IAM prévoit que les grévistes reçoivent 250 dollars par semaine à partir de la troisième semaine d’arrêt de travail.

title: Editor believed Stormy Daniels Trump affair story, texts at trial show
text: Tabloid executive David Pecker testified Thursday that National Enquirer's top editor thought porn star Stormy Daniels' alleged sexual relationship with Donald Trump was a true story. On the seventh day of Trump's trial for 34 counts of falsifying business records, Pecker, the former head of National Enquirer parent company American Media Inc., took the witness stand again. After testifying about the calls that led to the publication paying former Playboy model Karen McDougal $150,000 for rights to her story, including an alleged affair with Trump, Pecker recounted internal discussions about Daniels. Trump denies Daniels' claim and that he broke any laws. The jury saw texts between Pecker and Dylan Howard, the editor in chief at the National Enquirer at the time. Pecker said Howard was unable to travel for the trial, but Thursday's testimony provided insight about what the publication thought about Daniels' story. Trump trial live updates: David Pecker testifies about contract with Karen McDougal 'This story is true:' Dylan Howard texted David Pecker about Stormy Daniels Howard texted Pecker that a woman wanted $120,000 for her story, according to texts shown to the jury at Trump's hush money trial. Pecker testified the woman he was referencing was Stormy Daniels. "I know the denials were made in the past – but this story is true," Howard's texts shown to the jurors said, adding that the woman had other offers from "Mail" and "GMA." Pecker testified he refused to buy Stormy Daniels' story Pecker said he refused to buy Stormy Daniels' story. He texted Dylan Howard: "We can't pay 120k." Pecker explained on the stand that he was not a bank and had already paid hush money to Dino Sajudin and Karen McDougal to help Trump. Sajudin was a doorman at Trump Tower who alleged Trump had a love child with a housekeeper in the building. Pecker testified Tuesday that he did not believe Sajudin's story. Pecker also said he didn't want to be involved with a porn star. "Perhaps I call Michael and advise him and he can take it from there, and handle," Howard responded to Pecker, referring to Trump lawyer Michael Cohen, according to text messages displayed to the jury. After Pecker refused to buy Stormy Daniels' story, Cohen was upset and told Pecker the boss "would be furious with me," Pecker testified. Pecker still insisted he wouldn't go forward with purchasing it. Who is Stormy Daniels? Stormy Daniels , born Stephanie Clifford, is an adult film star. Daniels claims she had an affair with Trump in 2006, months after Melania Trump gave birth to Barron Trump. Cohen paid her $130,000 to stay quiet about the alleged affair ahead of the 2016 presidential election. Trump's subsequent reimbursement of Cohen, which he listed as legal expenses, is at the heart of prosecutors' allegation that the payments constituted an illegal campaign contribution by Cohen that Trump tried to hide by falsifying records. Who is David Pecker? David Pecker , former CEO and president of American Media Inc., is the first witness on the stand at Trump's Manhattan criminal trial . Pecker has testified that he was frequently in touch with Michael Cohen leading up to the 2016 election. Pecker said he promised to be "eyes and ears" about women selling stories about Trump, as part of a bigger effort to try to help his presidential campaign. The company was also fined $187,500 by the FEC for helping Trump's election, but the Justice Department granted Pecker immunity from prosecution. Contributing: Bart Jansen

title: Russian footballers received certificates from the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation for helping the occupiers - all the latest news today – 112.ua
text: Russian footballers received certificates from the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation for helping the occupiers. Four footballers received certificates from the Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation. The Volunteer Corps of the Ministry of Defense of Russia awarded certificates to CSKA goalkeeper Igor Akinfeev, Khimki defender Georgy Dzhikiya, Zenit striker Alexander Sobolev, and Pari NN defender Stanislav Magkeev. The footballers were thanked for "providing humanitarian aid and delivering the necessary equipment for the fulfillment of combat tasks to liberate new territories of Russia". The controversial deputy of the State Duma of Russia, Svetlana Zhurova, also expressed praise for the players: “Well done! Many people often provide help, they just don't publicize it, and then suddenly, gratitude appears for everyone. Probably, they didn't shout from every corner that they were doing this. Charitable help is usually provided this way. Then the people they helped thank them. And when it is announced to the whole country...” Alexander Sobolev was listed on the "Myrotvorets" website, where he is considered an accomplice in the crimes of the Russian authorities against Ukraine and its citizens. He participated in an event where footballers entered the match along with the children of participants in the Russian aggression against Ukraine. The event was organized by the "Defenders of the Fatherland" fund, which provides assistance to Russian occupiers and their families. All children participating in the event had the emblem of this fund on their shirts. During the match, the players held the hands of the children of Russian occupiers. Alexander Sobolev, born on March 7, 1997, in Barnaul, played for the Russian national football team. He played 14 matches and scored 6 goals. Sobolev also twice received the award for the best player of the month in the Russian Premier League. title: KEEPING IT IN THE FAMILY: Annual conference helps family owned businesses thrive - Top World News Today
text: In the U.S. nearly all business is family business. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, about 90% of American businesses are family-owned or controlled. Yet only a third of all family businesses are passed along to the next generation. Those are statistics John Resnick is hoping to change. “Southwest Florida is rich with family businesses. But there’s no formal education you can turn to, to learn how to navigate from generation to generation,” said Resnick, co-founder of the Resnick-Wynn Family Business Conference. Thursday was the third annual conference, which features family owned businesses from throughout southwest Florida. The goal is to network with other business owners, share success stories and cautionary tales. Resnick says one of the biggest challenges for business owners is stepping aside to let another generation lead. “It takes the older generations willing to let go and allow the younger generations to come in with their contributions. So, each generation has to respect their strengths and weaknesses,” said Resnick. For this year’s Keynote Speaker, passing the business torch has become a family tradition. Jonathan Tisch, Co-Chairman of Loews Corporation, was the third generation of his family to run the luxury hotel brand. His nephew now runs the day-to-day operations. “Family businesses are complicated. They’re a beast onto themselves,” Tisch said. “It’s a very difficult challenging world, where things are changing rapidly. I say that everyone is in the technology business nowadays, because technology touches everything that we do.” GOP Rep. author: HEATHER ROUSSEAU The Roanoke Times
title: A link to hope is now available in Roanoke area
text: People who are struggling now have a single online platform to visit that will help connect them with resources in the community. Roanoke is the first city in the nation to launch [Link2Hope](http://link2hoperoanoke.org/). A launch event for the online platform took place on Thursday at First Baptist Roanoke. The platform currently has 150 different uses including area volunteers, families, organizations and churches. It is managed through Friendship House, a religious-based nonprofit community-outreach organization. Nancy Friesen, lead coordinator with Link to Hope and Restoring Hope coordinator at Friendship House said individuals can both post needs and meet needs for others as well using the platform. “Roanoke is the perfect size city for it,” Friesen said. “We are a small city, but we have all the big city problems. We have a high poverty rate, drug abuse and lack of affordable housing.” People are also reading… Individuals can seek help for a variety of needs such as household repairs, financial advice, transportation and where to find area food pantry providers. “There’s some give and take, Friesen said. “We love it because it builds community.” For more, go to [link2hoperoanoke.org](http://link2hoperoanoke.org).
